thread.title: Bonds: Dovish Fed remarks, German data mark session
thread.title_full: Bonds: Dovish Fed remarks, German data mark session

title: Bonds: Dovish Fed remarks, German data mark session
text:
33.15 -0.70 
LONDON (ShareCast) - (ShareCast News) - Sovereign bond markets were mostly higher at the end of the week following on the heels of a dovish set of Fed meeting minutes, on Thursday evening. Reinforcing that tone, at least one Fed speaker, the president of the Federal Reserve bank of Atlanta (BSE: ATLANTA.BO - news ) , Dennis Lockhart, seemed noticeably less hawkish in his latest remarks. 
Lockhart told an audience he still expected rate 'lift-off' to come in 2015. However: "you should detect from the way I framed my remarks that I am slightly less confident today than I was six weeks ago," he added. 
His words weighed on 10-year US Treasury note yields, which slipped by two basis points to 2.09%. 
Acting as a backdrop, the latest German and US industrial production and wholesale inventory figures underwhelmed. 
The former took the lustre off Bunds, pushing the yield on the benchmark issue of German government debt higher by three basis points to 0.62%. 
Spanish debt of a similar maturity on the other hand was roughly unchanged. 
Speaking from Lima, Peru European Central Bank president Mario Draghi said "developments surrounding the slower growth in emerging-market economies are posing renewed risks to the euro-area outlook."
